tit.cmt: ローマ字表記にしました。

sen.j: 倭（わ、やまと）は、紀元前から中国各王朝が日本列島を中心とする地域およびその住人を指す際に用いた呼称である。
sen.e: 倭(Wa or Yamato) was the name used by Chinese dynasties to refer to the area centering the Japanese Archipelago and people living there since the days before Christ.
倭(Wa or Yamato) was the name used by Chinese dynasties to refer to the area centering the Japanese Archipelago and people living there since the days before Christ.
倭 (Wa or Yamato) was the name used by Chinese dynasties to refer to the area centering the Japanese Archipelago and people living there since the days before Christ.

sen.j: 倭の住人を倭人と呼ぶこともあった。
sen.e: People living in Wa were sometimes called Wajin.
People living in Wa were sometimes called Wajin.
People living in Wa were sometimes called Wajin.

sen.j: 倭および倭人の指し示す範囲は時代によって変遷した。
sen.e: What Wa or Wajin refers to has changed over time.
What Wa or Wajin refers to has changed over time.
What Wa or Wajin refers to has changed over time.

sen.j: 紀元前後頃から7世紀末頃にかけて、日本列島の政治勢力も倭もしくは倭国と自称した。
sen.e: From around the beginning of the first century to the end of the seventh century, political powers in the Japanese Archpelago called themselves Wa or Wakoku.
From around the beginning of the first century to the end of the seventh century, political powers in the Japanese Archpelago called themselves Wa or Wakoku.
From around the beginning of the first century to the end of the seventh century, political powers in the Japanese Archipelago called themselves Wa or Wakoku.

tit.j: 倭・倭人の語源・語義

sen.j: 「倭」は「委（ゆだねる）」に人が加わった字形。
sen.e: The Chinese character '倭' is composed of two parts meaning 'entrusting' and person, respectively.
The Chinese character '倭' is composed of two parts meaning 'entrusting' and person, respectively.
The Chinese character '倭' is composed of two parts meaning 'entrusting' and person, respectively.

sen.j: よって解字は「ゆだねしたがう」となる。
sen.e: Therefore, the meaning is to 'entrust and obey.'
Therefore, the meaning is to 'entrust and obey.'
Therefore, the meaning is to 'entrust and obey.'

sen.j: 日本列島に住む人々が倭・倭人と呼称されるに至った由来にはいくつかの説がある。
sen.e: There are several views about how people living in the Japanes Archpelago came to be called Wa or Wajin.
There are several views about how people living in the Japanes Archpelago came to be called Wa or Wajin.
There are several views about how people living in the Japanese Archipelago came to be called Wa or Wajin.

sen.j: 魏 (三国)の官人、如淳は「人面に入れ墨する（委する）」習俗をもって倭の由来と論じたが、臣瓚や顔師古らから、倭と委の音が異なることなどを理由に否定されている。
sen.e: 如淳, a government official of Wei dynasty (Three States Period), considered the custom of 'getting a tatto on their faces (entrusting)' to be the origin of Wa, but Shinsan and Gan Shiko (Yan Shigu) denied the possibility because of such reasons such as the phonetic difference between 倭 and 委.

如淳, a government official of Wei dynasty (Three States Period), considered the custom of 'getting a tatto on their faces (entrusting)' to be the origin of Wa, but Shinsan and Gan Shiko (Yan Shigu) denied the possibility because of such reasons such as the phonetic difference between 倭 and 委.

如淳, a government official of Wei dynasty (Three States Period), considered the custom of 'getting a tattoo on their faces (entrusting)' to be the origin of Wa, but Shinsan and Gan Shiko (Yan Shigu) denied the possibility because of such reasons such as the phonetic difference between 倭 and 委.

sen.j: その他、平安時代初期の『弘仁私記』序はある人の説として、倭人が自らを「わ」（われ）と称したことから倭となった、とする説を記している。
sen.e: The preface of "Koninshiki" introduced a theory by someone regarding the origin of the name that Wajin called themselves 'Wa' (meaning 'I', 'me' or 'we', 'us' in Japanese).
The preface of "Koninshiki" introduced a theory by someone regarding the origin of the name that Wajin called themselves 'Wa' (meaning 'I', 'me' or 'we', 'us' in Japanese).
The preface of "Koninshiki" of the early Heian period introduced a theory by someone regarding the origin of the name that Wajin called themselves 'Wa' (meaning 'I,' 'me' or 'we,' 'us' in Japanese).

sen.j: また、『説文解字』に倭の語義が従順とあることから、一条兼良が「倭人の人心が従順だったからだ」と唱え（『日本書紀纂疏』）、後世の儒者はこれに従う者が多かった。
sen.e: Since "Setsumon-kaiji" (Chinese classic dictionary) explained 倭 means obedience, Kanera ICHIJO said "because Wajin were obedient in nature' ("Nihonshoki sanso"), and many Confucianists followed the theory in later ages.

Since "Setsumon-kaiji" (Chinese classic dictionary) defines 倭 to mean obedience, Kanera ICHIJO said "because Wajin were obedient in nature' ("Nihonshoki sanso"), and many Confucianists followed the theory in later ages.

Since "Setsumon-kaiji" (Chinese classic dictionary) defines 倭 to mean obedience, Kanera ICHIJO said 'because Wajin were obedient in nature' ("Nihonshoki sanso"), and many Confucianists followed the theory in later ages.

sen.j: 木下順庵らは、小柄な人びと（矮人）だから倭と呼ばれたとする説を述べている。
sen.e: Junan KINOSHITA explained that "they were called Wa because they were little people (dwarfs)."
Junan KINOSHITA explained that "they were called Wa because they were little people (dwarfs)."
Junan KINOSHITA explained that "they were called Wa because they were little people (dwarfs)."

sen.j: 新井白石は『古史通或問』にて「オホクニ」の音訳が倭国であるとした。
sen.e: Hakuseki ARAI said in "Koshitsuwakumon" that 倭国 (in Chinese) is the phonetic translation of 'Okuni.'
Hakuseki ARAI said in "Koshitsuwakumon" that 倭国 (in Chinese) is the phonetic translation of 'Okuni.'
Hakuseki ARAI said in "Koshitsuwakumon" that 倭国 (in Chinese) is the phonetic translation of 'Okuni.'

sen.j: このように多くの説が立てられたが、定かなものはない。
sen.e: So many theories including the above-mentioned have been built up, but none is proved.
So many theories including the above-mentioned have been created, but none have been proven.
So many theories including the above-mentioned have been created, but none have been proven.

sen.j: 隋唐代に韻書と呼ばれる字書がいくつも編まれ、それらに倭の音は「ワ」「ヰ」両音が示されており、ワ音の倭は東海の国名として、ヰ音の倭は従順を表す語として、説明されている。
sen.e: At the ages of Sui and Tang Dynasties, several glossaries called Insho (Chinese dictionary arranged by finals) were compiled, in which the reading of 倭 is 'wa' and 'wi' and 'wa' is said to be the name of a country in Tokai and 'wi' is said to be a word meaning obedience.

During the Sui and Tang Dynasties, several glossaries called Insho (Chinese dictionary arranged by finals) were compiled, in which the reading of 倭 is 'wa' and 'wi' and 'wa' is said to be the name of a country in Tokai and 'wi' is said to be a word meaning obedience.

During the Sui and Tang Dynasties, several glossaries called Insho (Chinese dictionary arranged by finals) were compiled, in which the reading of 倭 is 'wa' and 'wi' and 'wa' is said to be the name of a country in Tokai and 'wi' is said to be a word meaning obedience.

sen.j: すなわち、隋唐の時代から国名としての倭の語義は不明とされていた。
sen.e: Therefore, the meaning of the word Wa as a country name has been unknown since the ages of Sui and Tang Dynasties.
Therefore, the meaning of the word Wa as a country name has been unknown since the ages of Sui and Tang Dynasties.
Therefore, the meaning of the word Wa as a country name has been unknown since the ages of Sui and Tang Dynasties.

sen.j: また、平安時代の『日本書紀私記』丁本においても、倭の由来は不明であるとする。
sen.e: "Nihonshoki Shiki"丁本 (The Private Record of Chronicles of Japan) also said that the origin of Wa is unknown.
"Nihonshoki Shiki"丁本 (The Private Record of Chronicles of Japan) also said that the origin of Wa is unknown.
"Nihonshoki Shiki"丁本 (The Private Record of Chronicles of Japan) also said that the origin of Wa is unknown.

sen.j: さらに、本居宣長も『国号考』で倭の由来が不詳であることを述べている。
sen.e: And Norinaga MOTOORI also said in "Kokugoko" that the origin of wa is unknown.
And Norinaga MOTOORI also said in "Kokugoko" that the origin of wa is unknown.
And Norinaga MOTOORI also said in "Kokugoko" that the origin of wa is unknown.

sen.j: これらから、倭の意味は不明とするのが妥当と見る研究者もいる。
sen.e: Based on those references, some scolars think it appropriate to see the meaning of Wa unknown.
Based on those references, some scolars think it appropriate to see the meaning of Wa unknown.
Based on those references, some scholars think it appropriate to see the meaning of Wa unknown.

sen.j: ところで、倭は悪字かどうかについての議論もある。
sen.e: By the way, there is a dicussion whether the Chinese character 倭 is a evil character.
There is a dicussion as to whether the Chinese character 倭 is an evil character.
There is a discussion as to whether the Chinese character 倭 is an evil character.

sen.j: 『詩経』（小雅、四牡）などにおける用例から見て、倭は必ずしも侮蔑の意味を含まないとする意見がある。
sen.e: Some says 倭 does not necessarily imply insulting meaning judging from the examples in "Sikyo" (Chinese Poetry book)(Shoga (aristocracy).
Some says 倭 does not necessarily imply an insult judging from the examples in "Sikyo" (Chinese Poetry book)(Shoga (aristocracy).
Some says 倭 does not necessarily imply an insult judging from the examples in "Sikyo" (Chinese Poetry book) (Shoga (aristocracy).
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: 一方、卑弥呼や邪馬台国と同様に非佳字をあてることにより、中華世界から見た夷狄であることを表すとする意見もある。
sen.e: But others says 倭 means iteki (barbarians) seen from China because the ominous character is used as in Himiko (first known ruler of Japan) and Yamatai Koku (Yamatai Kingdom).
But others says 倭 means iteki (barbarians) seen from China because the ominous character is used as in Himiko (first known ruler of Japan) and Yamatai Koku (Yamatai Kingdom).
But others says 倭 means iteki (barbarians) seen from China because the ominous character is used as in Himiko (first known ruler of Japan) and Yamatai Koku (Yamatai Kingdom).

sen.j: 倭・倭人関連の中国文献も参照のこと。
sen.e: See chinese literatures related to Wa or Wajin.
See chinese literatures related to Wa or Wajin.
See Chinese literatures related to Wa or Wajin.

sen.j: 中国文献においては『論衡』に「倭人」が見えている。
sen.e: Description of 'Wajin' is seen in a Chinese literature"Ronko" (Discourses weighed in the balance).
Description of 'Wajin' as seen in the Chinese literature"Ronko" (Discourses weighed in the balance).
Description of 'Wajin' as seen in the Chinese literature "Ronko" (Discourses weighed in the balance).
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: 同書は倭人が周王へ暢草（薬草）を献上したと記述しており、早ければ武王紀元前11世紀末頃、記述のある成王とすれば紀元前10世紀頃の出来事である可能性がある。
sen.e: The literature mentioned that Wajin presented the King of Zhou with Choso (medicinal plants), which was possibly in the late 11th century B.C. under the reign of King Wu of Zhou at the earliest, or in the 10th century B.C. if it was at the time of King Cheng.

The literature mentioned that Wajin presented the King of Zhou with Choso (medicinal plants), which was possibly in the late 11th century B.C. under the reign of King Wu of Zhou at the earliest, or in the 10th century B.C. if it was during the time of King Cheng.

The literature mentioned that Wajin presented the King of Zhou with Choso (medicinal plants), which was possibly in the late 11th century B.C. under the reign of King Wu of Zhou at the earliest, or in the 10th century B.C. if it was during the time of King Cheng.

sen.j: 当時の日本列島は縄文時代晩期ないし弥生時代初期であり、この時期から日本列島と中国との通交が始まったとする見解もあるが、『論衡』の成立が1世紀であるため、同書に依拠することに慎重な見解が有力である。
sen.e: The Japanese Archipelago was then in the late Jomon period or early Yayoi period, and some see that the trade between China and Japan began around that time, but since "Ronko" was written in the first century, it is generally considered that the book should be taken with caution.

The Japanese Archipelago was then in the late Jomon period or early Yayoi period, and some believe that trade between China and Japan began around that time, but since "Ronko" was written in the first century, it is generally considered that the book should be taken with caution.

The Japanese Archipelago was then in the late Jomon period or early Yayoi period, and some believe that trade between China and Japan began around that time, but since "Ronko" was written in the first century, it is generally considered that the book should be taken with caution.

sen.j: 『山海経』（戦国-秦漢期成立）には倭が中国東北部にあった燕_(春秋)国に服属していたという記述があり、紀元前6-4世紀頃のことと考えられているが、同書についても依拠することに慎重な見解が存在する。
sen.e: There is a description in "Sengaikyo" (oldest topography of China), written sometime between the Warring States Period and Qin/Han Dynasty) that says Wa was obedient to Yan (Chunqiu period), therefore it is considered to be in the period from the sixth century to fourth century B.C. but some think the book should also be taken with caution.

There is a description in "Sengaikyo" (oldest topography of China), written sometime between the Warring States Period and Qin/Han Dynasty) that says Wa was obedient to Yan (Chunqiu period), therefore it is considered to be in the period from the sixth century to fourth century B.C. but some think the book should also be taken with caution.

There is a description in "Sengaikyo" (oldest topography of China), written sometime between the Warring States Period and Qin/Han Dynasty) that says Wa was obedient to Yan (Chunqiu period) which was in the northeast of China, therefore it is considered to be in the period from the sixth century to fourth century B.C. but some think the book should also be taken with caution.

sen.j: 紀元前2世紀-紀元前後ごろの時期には、倭人は定期的に前漢へ朝貢しており、また約100の政治集団（国）を形成していた（『漢書地理志』）。
sen.e: In the period from the second century B.C. to around the beginning of the first century, Wajin paid tribute to the Former Han Dynasty on a regular basis and formed about 100 political groups (countries) ("Kanjo Chirishi" (Historical records of the Han Dynasty)).

In the period from the second century B.C. to around the beginning of the first century, Wajin paid tribute to the Former Han Dynasty on a regular basis and formed about 100 political groups (countries) ("Kanjo Chirishi" (Historical records of the Han Dynasty)).

In the period from the second century B.C. to around the beginning of the first century, Wajin paid tribute to the Former Han Dynasty on a regular basis and formed about 100 political groups (countries) ("Kanjo Chirishi" (Historical records of the Han Dynasty)).

sen.j: 1世紀中葉になると北部九州（博多湾沿岸）にあったとされる倭奴国が後漢へ朝貢している（『後漢書』）が、これは北部九州における倭人の政治集団の統合が進み、その代表として倭奴国が後漢へ遣使したと考えられている。
sen.e: In the middle of the first century, 倭奴国, which is thought to have been located in northern Kyusyu (the coast of Hakata Bay), paid tribute to the Later Han Dynasty ("Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty)), which is tought to indicate that Wajin political groups in Northern Kyushu were consolidated and 倭奴国 sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty as the representative.

In the middle of the first century, 倭奴国, which is thought to have been located in northern Kyusyu (the coast of Hakata Bay), paid tribute to the Later Han Dynasty ("Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty)), which is tought to indicate that Wajin political groups in Northern Kyushu were consolidated and 倭奴国 sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty as the representative.

In the middle of the first century, 倭奴国, which is thought to have been located in northern Kyushu (the coast of Hakata Bay), paid tribute to the Later Han Dynasty ("Gokanjo" (Historical records of the Later Han Dynasty)), which is thought to indicate that Wajin political groups in Northern Kyushu were consolidated and 倭奴国 sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty as the representative.

sen.j: その約50年後の2世紀初頭には、倭国王帥升が後漢へ遣使している。
sen.e: About 50 years later in the early second century, Suisho, the King of Wakoku, sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty.
About 50 years later in the early second century, Suisho, the King of Wakoku, sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty.
About 50 years later in the early second century, Suisho, the King of Wakoku, sent an envoy to the Later Han Dynasty.

sen.j: 文献に名の残る日本史上最古の人物である帥升は、史料上、倭国王を称した最初の人物でもある。
sen.e: Suisho, who is the first Japanee person in history appeared in literature, called himself the King of Wakoku for the first time in history.
Suisho, who was the first Japanese person in history to appear in literature, called himself the King of Wakoku.
Suisho, who was the first Japanese person in history to appear in literature, called himself the King of Wakoku.

sen.j: さらに「倭国」という語もこの時初めて現れている。
sen.e: The term 'Wakoku" also appeared for the first time then.
The term 'Wakoku" also appeared for the first time then.
The term 'Wakoku' also appeared for the first time then.

sen.j: これらのことから、この時期に倭・倭人を代表する倭国と呼ばれる政治勢力が形成されたと考えられている。
sen.e: In view of these records, it is considered that a political groups called Wakoku representing Wa or Wajin were formed at that time.
In view of these records, it is considered that a political group called Wakoku representing Wa or Wajin were formed at that time.
In view of these records, it is considered that a political group called Wakoku representing Wa or Wajin were formed at that time.

sen.j: これ以降、7世紀最末期までの間、倭・倭人を代表する/統合する政治勢力は「倭国」を称し続けた。
sen.e: From around that time till the very end of the seventh century, the political powers representing and consolidating Wa or Wajin continued to called themselves 'Wakoku'.
From around that time till the very end of the seventh century, the political powers representing and consolidating Wa or Wajin continued to call themselves 'Wakoku'.
From around that time till the very end of the seventh century, the political powers representing and consolidating Wa or Wajin continued to call themselves 'Wakoku.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置移動しました。

sen.j: （→詳しくは倭国を参照）
sen.e: (Please refer to "Wakoku" for more details.)

sen.j: 帥升の後、3世紀前半に活躍した卑弥呼も魏 (三国)の国から親魏倭王の称号を授かった。
sen.e: After the days of Sisho, Himiko in the early third century was also given the title of Shingi Wao (the king of Wa) by the Wei Dynasty (Three States Period).
After the days of Sisho, Himiko in the early third century was also given the title of Shingi Wao (the king of Wa) by the Wei Dynasty (Three States Period).
After the days of Sisho, Himiko in the early third century was also given the title of Shingi Wao (the king of Wa) by the Wei Dynasty (Three States Period).

sen.j: 3世紀中葉-後期に成立したとされるヤマト王権の王たちも対外的には倭王・倭国王を称したと考えられており、実際に4世紀後期から5世紀末にかけて中国王朝と活発な通交を重ねた諸王も中国に対して倭王または倭国王を称している（倭の五王）。
sen.e: It is considered that kings of the Yamato Dynasty, which was supposedly established in mid or later third century, externally called themselves the King of Wa or the King of Wakoku, and in fact, Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation) who were actively involved in the friendly relations with Chinese Dynasties from the late fourth to the late fifth century called themselves the King of Wakoku (The five kings of Wa).

It is considered that kings of the Yamato Dynasty, which was supposedly established in mid or later third century, externally called themselves the King of Wa or the King of Wakoku, and in fact, Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation) who were actively involved in friendly relations with Chinese Dynasties from the late fourth to late fifth century called themselves the King of Wakoku (The five kings of Wa).

It is considered that kings of the Yamato Dynasty, which was supposedly established in mid or later third century, externally called themselves the King of Wa or the King of Wakoku, and in fact, Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation) who were actively involved in friendly relations with Chinese Dynasties from the late fourth to late fifth century called themselves the King of Wakoku (The five kings of Wa).

sen.j: 607年の遣隋使では、倭王ではなく「日出處天子」と称したことが『隋書』に残されている。
sen.e: According to the description in the "Zuisho" (the Book of the Sui Dynasty), the Japanese envoy to Sui Dynasty in 607 used the expression 'the Son of Heaven in the land where the sun rises' instead of the King of Wa.

According to the description in the "Zuisho" (the Book of the Sui Dynasty), the Japanese envoy to Sui Dynasty in 607 used the expression 'the Son of Heaven in the land where the sun rises' instead of the King of Wa.

According to the description in the "Zuisho" (the Book of the Sui Dynasty), the Japanese envoy to Sui Dynasty in 607 used the expression 'the Son of Heaven in the land where the sun rises' instead of the King of Wa.

sen.j: これには、中国と対等の地位で通交するため、あえて倭を称さなかったとする見解がある。
sen.e: There is a view that they dared not use the term Wa in an attempt to have relations with China on an equal footing.
There is a view that they dared not use the term Wa in an attempt to have relations with China on an equal footing.
There is a view that they dared not use the term Wa in an attempt to have relations with China on an equal footing.

sen.j: しかしこのことは中国との外交に大きな影響を生じさせたため、その後再び倭を称するようになった。
sen.e: However, this had a great impact on the relations with China, and they again called themselves Wa thereafter.
However, this had a great impact on relations with China, and they again called themselves Wa thereafter.
However, this had a great impact on relations with China, and they again called themselves Wa thereafter.

sen.j: 660年、百済が滅びると倭国は復興を企図、唐・新羅と白村江の戦いを663年におこなうが、敗れた。
sen.e: After Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) was overthrown in 660, Wakoku fought the Battle of Hakusonko (Battle of Baekgang) against Tang and Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) in an attempt to resuscitate Kudara, but ended up in defeat.

After Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) was overthrown in 660, Wakoku fought the Battle of Hakusonko (Battle of Baekgang) against Tang and Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) in an attempt to resuscitate Kudara, but ended up in defeat.

After Kudara (Baekje, Paekche) was overthrown in 660, Wakoku fought the Battle of Hakusonko (Battle of Baekgang) against Tang and Shiragi (ancient Korean kingdom) in an attempt to resuscitate Kudara, but ended up in defeat.

sen.j: これを受け倭国内部では、国制整備・国力増強への志向が急速に強まった。
sen.e: Following the failure, aspirations for developing domestic system and increasing national power were rapidly intensified in Wakoku.
Following this failure, aspirations to develop a domestic system and nationalistic powers rapidly intensified in Wakoku.
Following this failure, aspirations to develop a domestic system and nationalistic powers rapidly intensified in Wakoku.

sen.j: そうした中で新しい国家体制、すなわち律令制の構築が精力的に進められていき、7世紀最末期には新国家体制を規定する大宝律令の編纂がほぼ完了したが、同律令施行直前の701年前後に国号が倭・倭国から日本へ改められたとされている。
sen.e: Amid the circumstance, the construction of new state system, Ritsuryo system advanced with great drive and by the very end of the seventh century, Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) which defined the new form of government was completed, and in or around 701just before the enforcement of the ritsuryo, Wa or Wakoku was renamed NIppon or Nihon.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明、以後便宜的に'Nippon'で統一しています。
sen.e: Amid this, the construction of a new state system, the Ritsuryo system steadily advanced and by the very end of the seventh century, Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) which defined the new form of government was completed, and in or around 701just before the enforcement of the ritsuryo, Wa or Wakoku was renamed Nippon or Nihon.

Amid this, the construction of a new state system, the Ritsuryo system steadily advanced and by the very end of the seventh century, Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) which defined the new form of government was completed, and in or around 701just before the enforcement of the ritsuryo, Wa or Wakoku was renamed Nippon or Nihon.

sen.j: 以後、日本列島の中心的な政治勢力が倭を自称することは絶えた。
sen.e: After that, main political powers in Japan stopped calling themselves Wa.
After that, the main political powers in Japan stopped calling themselves Wa.
After that, the main political powers in Japan stopped calling themselves Wa.

sen.j: このときの国号改称について、新唐書（『唐書』）、旧唐書（『舊唐書』）に「倭という名称をきらって日本へ改称した」という内容の記述が残されている。
sen.e: Shintojo (New Book of Tang)("Tojo" (Book of Tang)) and Kutojo ("Old Tang History")have records in relation to the change of the name, which says the name was changed to Nippon in disgust of the name, Wa.

Shintojo (New Book of Tang)("Tojo" (Book of Tang)) and Kutojo ("Old Tang History")have records in relation to the change of the name, which says the name was changed to Nippon in disgust of the name, Wa.

Shintojo (New Book of Tang) ("Tojo" (Book of Tang)) and Kutojo ("Old Tang History") have records in relation to the change of the name, which says the name was changed to Nippon in disgust of the name, Wa.
sen.cmt: スペース挿入しました。

sen.j: また、両書には「元々小国だった日本が倭国を併合した」という内容の記述もあり、これは天武天皇が弘文天皇の近江朝廷を滅亡させた壬申の乱を表していると一般的には理解されている。
sen.e: And the both books mentioned that 'Nippon, which used to be a small country, annexed Wakoku' and this description is generally considered to be the reference to the Jinshin War, in which Emperor Tenmu ruined the Omi Dynasty of the Emperor Kobun.

Both books mentioned that 'Nippon, which used to be a small country, annexed Wakoku' and this description is generally considered to be the reference to the Jinshin War, in which Emperor Tenmu ruined the Omi Dynasty of the Emperor Kobun.

Both books mentioned that 'Nippon, which used to be a small country, annexed Wakoku' and this description is generally considered to be the reference to the Jinshin War, in which Emperor Tenmu ruined the Omi Dynasty of the Emperor Kobun.

sen.j: また、朝鮮半島の史書『三国史記』「新羅本紀」文武王十年（670年）12月条には、「倭国、号を日本に更む。自ら言う、日出づるに近きを以て名を為す」とある。
sen.e: In the clause of December, 670 of Shilla Hongi (History of Shilla), "Samguk Sagi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), a history book of Korean Peninsula, there is a description that says ' Wakoku was renamed Nippon because the land is close to the place where the sun rises.'

In the clause of December, 670 of Shilla Hongi (History of Shilla), "Samguk Sagi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), a history book of Korean Peninsula, there is a description that says ' Wakoku was renamed Nippon because the land is close to the place where the sun rises.'

In the clause of December, 670 of Shilla Hongi (History of Shilla), "Samguk Sagi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), a history book of Korean Peninsula, there is a description that says 'Wakoku was renamed Nippon because the land is close to the place where the sun rises.'
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: その後も日本国内では、しばらく日本を指して「倭」と呼ぶこともあったが、奈良時代中期頃（天平勝宝年間）から同音好字の「和」が併用されるようになり、次第に「和」が主流となっていった。
sen.e: Even after that, 'Wa' was sometimes used to refer to Japan domestically, but since the mid-Nara period, '和', which has the same pronunciation but has good meaning, came in use along with 倭 and gradually became the mainstream.

Even after that, 'Wa' was sometimes used to refer to Japan domestically, but since the mid-Nara period, '和', which has the same pronunciation but has a positive meaning, came in use along with 倭 and gradually became the mainstream.

Even after that, 'Wa' was sometimes used to refer to Japan domestically, but since the mid-Nara period, '和,' which has the same pronunciation but has a positive meaning, came in use along with 倭 and gradually became the mainstream.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動しました。

sen.j: その後中世から近世にかけても、中国から大和民族を指す場合には「倭」と呼ぶことがあった（→例えば倭寇を参照）。
sen.e: Afterward from the middle ages to the early-modern times, '倭' was sometimes used to refer to Yamato race by Chinese.
Afterward from the middle ages to the early-modern times, '倭' was sometimes used to refer to the Yamato race by Chinese.
Afterward from the middle ages to the early-modern times, '倭' was sometimes used to refer to the Yamato race by Chinese (please refer to "wako" (Japanese pirates) as an example).

sen.j: この場合、琉球や台湾などを含め「中国から東の海を隔てた土地から来る人々」を総称する漠然とした呼称でもあったようである。
sen.e: In that case, it was a vague name generally referring to 'the people coming from the land including Ryukyu and Taiwan separated by the eastern sea of China.
In that case, it was a vague name generally referring to 'the people coming from the land including Ryukyu and Taiwan separated by the eastern sea of China.
In that case, it was a vague name generally referring to 'the people coming from the land including Ryukyu and Taiwan separated by the eastern sea of China.'

sen.j: 中世以後、日本の国に対しては、倭（国）、日本の他に、扶桑（国）、東瀛という呼称もある。
sen.e: After the middle ages, other than Wa (koku) and Nippon, Fuso and Toei were also used.
After the middle ages, other than Wa (koku) and Nippon, Fuso and Toei were also used.
After the middle ages, other than Wa (koku) and Nippon, Fuso and Toei were also used.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島の高麗・李氏朝鮮では、国内文書や史書などに「倭」「倭奴」の記述が見られるが、これについて、高麗・朝鮮が日本を蔑視していたことの表れだとする指摘がある。
sen.e: Descriptions of 'wa' and '倭奴' can be found in domestic literatures and history books at the ages of Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty in Korean Peninsula, and some people says that is the express of contempt for Japan by Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty.

Descriptions of 'wa' and '倭奴' can be found in domestic literatures and history books at the ages of Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty in Korean Peninsula, and some people says that is the express of contempt for Japan by Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty.

Descriptions of 'wa' and '倭奴' can be found in domestic literatures and history books at the ages of Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty in Korean Peninsula, and some people says that is the express of contempt for Japan by Goryeo and Joseon Dynasty.

sen.j: 公式の場において使われることはないが、現代の中華人民共和国や大韓民国・朝鮮民主主義人民共和国などでは、日本や日本人に対して侮蔑的な意味を込めて「倭」を用いることがある。
sen.e: 'Wa' is no longer used officially but is sometimes used with contemptuous meaning in Chines Republic, Korean Republic and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
Wa' is no longer used officially but is sometimes used as a contemptuous meaning in the Chinese Republic, Korean Republic and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
Wa' is no longer used officially but is sometimes used as a contemptuous meaning in the Chinese Republic, Korean Republic and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

sen.j: 侮蔑を強めるには、中国では倭寇、韓国・北朝鮮ではウェノムなどと表現される。
sen.e: To stress the sense of contempt, Wako in China and Wenomu in the South and North Korea are used.
To stress the sense of contempt, Wako in China and Wenomu in the South and North Korea are used.
To stress the sense of contempt, Wako in China and Wenomu in the South and North Korea are used.

sen.j: 異説
sen.e: Different opinion
Different opinion
Different opinion

sen.j: 紀元前から7世紀末まで日本を代表した政権は一貫して九州にあり、倭（ゐ）、大倭（たゐ）、俀（たゐ）と呼ばれていたとする九州王朝説があるが、主張に根拠が乏しい。
sen.e: There is a theory of Kyushu Dynasty which says the government representing Japan was located in Kyushu from the first century to the end of seventh century called Wi or Tawi, but it lacks grounds.

There is a theory of Kyushu Dynasty which says the government representing Japan was located in Kyushu from the first century to the end of seventh century called Wi or Tawi, but this lacks much evidence.

There is a theory of Kyushu Dynasty which says the government representing Japan was located in Kyushu from before Christ to the end of seventh century called Wi or Tawi, but this lacks much evidence.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ修正しました。
